description.narrative:
Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 In Asia, pro-growth policies backed by foreign direct investment (FDI), expansion of industrial sector and growing consumer demand, have led to rapid and significant gains in jobs, productivity and innovation. Asia has long been synonymous with rising economic future. The ASEAN sub-region is the world’s sixth largest economy—with a combined GDP of almost US$2.6 trillion—and the world’s fourth largest exporting economy. South Asia’s economic heft is also measured in superlatives. In 2017, the sub-region delivered more than 60% of global economic growth. With these figures in mind, some economist believe Asia will become the world’s largest economic region by 2030.
Fast-paced economic development has somehow come at the cost of human rights infringement and continuous environmental degradation with long-term consequences on the well-being of all. The situation is even direr for those living in poverty and the vulnerable groups like migrant labours, women workers, children, disabilities and indigenous people, who are marginalized by unequal socio-economic status and limited access to social welfare and protection.
The Guiding Principle Business and Human Rights endorsed by the UN Human Rights Council in 2011, is widely recognised as the normative framework guiding efforts to reduce or eliminate the adverse impact of business operations on human rights. The proposed regional programme “Business and Human Rights in Asia: Promoting Responsible Business Practices through Regional Partnerships (B+HR Asia)”, submitted by UNDP Regional Office Asia and Pacific, aims to promote the implementation of the UN Guiding Principles in Asia through regional efforts focused on advocacy, policy development, technical advisory support, capacity building, awareness raising, innovation platforms, regional peer learning events, and South-South cooperation. The programme is 5 year-duration from August 2018 – August 2023 covering 7 target countries in Southeast Asia and South Asia. The target countries are Bangladesh, India (for further study), Indonesia, Malaysia, Sri-Lanka, Thailand and Vietnam.
The programme will be implemented and managed as part of UNDP Regional Programme Asia and the Pacific by the team UNDP Bangkok Regional Hub (BRH). The programme’s long-term outcome is to contribute to sustainable business practices which strengthen human rights, empower women, and respect the environment are facilitated at the regional and national levels through the implementation of UN Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights. Throughout the programme duration, regional platform will be created to encourage peer learning and collaboration amongst the countries. Potential regional actors have been identified and will be pursued for partnerships in efforts to scale up the impacts to regional level as a pathway to sustainability.
It is anticipated that the above outcome would be derived from the following result areas of the programme. 1) Regional momentum strengthened toward implementation of the UN Guiding Principles 2) Development and implementation of regional and national legislative and policy frameworks, 3) Strengthen regional partnership architecture, made up of UN system, NHRI, CSO, and private sector actors working on B&HR, 4) Increased awareness of all regional stakeholders of the UNGPs and strengthened access to effective remedy for violations of human rights in the context of business operations, and 5) Strengthened policy coherence between regional Trade Agreements, International Investor Agreements, and UN Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights to enhance the region’s competitive positioning in attracting investment and increasing trade flows.

Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 I Asien har pro-tillväxtpolitiken med stöd av utländska direktinvesteringar (FDI), expansion av industrisektorn och en växande konsumentefterfrågan lett till snabba och betydande vinster avseende arbetstillfällen, produktivitet och innovation. Asien har länge varit synonymt med en ökande ekonomisk framtid. ASEAN-regionen är världens sjätte största ekonomi - med en sammanlagd BNP på nästan 2,6 biljoner US-dollar - och världens fjärde största exportekonomi. Sydasiens ekonomiska mäts också i superlativ. Under 2017 levererade regionen mer än 60% av den globala ekonomiska tillväxten. Med dessa siffror i åtanke tror en del ekonomer att Asien kommer att bli världens största ekonomiska region 2030.
Den snabba ekonomiska utvecklingen har skett på bekostnad av brist på respekt för de mänskliga rättigheterna och kontinuerlig miljöförstöring med långsiktiga konsekvenser för allas välbefinnande. Situationen är ännu svårare för dem som lever i fattigdom och de utsatta grupperna som migrantarbetare, kvinnliga arbetstagare, barn, funktionshindrade och ursprungsfolk, som marginaliseras av ojämlik socioekonomisk status och med begränsad tillgång till social välfärd och skydd.
Den vägledande principen om företag och mänskliga rättigheter som godkändes av FN: s råd för mänskliga rättigheter 2011 är allmänt erkänd som den normativa ramen som styr ansträngningar för att minska eller eliminera den negativa inverkan som företagsverksamhet kan påverkar de mänskliga rättigheterna. Det föreslagna regionala programmet ”Business and Human Rights in Asia: Promoting Responsible Business Practices through Regional Partnerships (B + HR Asia)”, inlämnat av UNDP Regional Office Asia and Pacific, syftar till att främja genomförandet av FN: s vägledande principer i Asien genom regionala ansträngningar fokuserade på påverkansarbete, policyutveckling, tekniskt rådgivnings, kapacitetsuppbyggnad, medvetandegörande , innovationsplattformar, regionala peer learning-evenemang och syd-syd samarbete. Programmet pågår i fem år från augusti 2018 - augusti 2023 och täcker 7 fokusländer i Sydostasien och Sydasien. Länderna är Bangladesh, Indien (för vidare studier), Indonesien, Malaysia, Sri-Lanka, Thailand och Vietnam.
Programmet kommer att implementeras och hanteras som en del av UNDP Regional Program Asia and the Pacific av teamet UNDP Bangkok Regional Hub (BRH). Programmets långsiktiga resultat är att bidra till hållbara affärsmetoder som stärker mänskliga rättigheter, stärker kvinnors situation och respekterar miljö vilket underlättas på regional och nationell nivå genom genomförandet av FN: s vägledande principer för företag och mänskliga rättigheter. Under programmets genomförande kommer regionala plattformen att skapas för att uppmuntra till inbördes lärande och samarbete mellan länderna. Potentiella regionala aktörer har identifierats och kommer att erbjudas partnerskap i ansträngningar att skala upp effekterna till en regional nivå som en väg att nå hållbarhet.
Det förväntas att ovanstående resultat kommer från följande resultatområden i programmet. 1) Regionalt momentum för stärkt genomförandet av FN: s vägledande principer 2) Utveckling och genomförande av regionala och nationella lagstiftnings- och politiska ramverk, 3) Stärka den regionala partnerskapsarkitekturen, bestående av FN-systemet, nationella MR-institutioner, civil samhället och privata sektorn som arbetar med B&HR , 4) Ökad medvetenhet om alla regionala intressenter för FNs vägledande principer för hållbart företagande och mänskliga rättigheter (UNGP) och stärkt tillgången till effektiva åtgärder för kränkningar av de mänskliga rättigheterna i samband med affärsverksamhet, och 5) Stärkt politisk samstämmighet mellan regionala handelsavtal, internationella investeringsavtal och FN: s vägledande principer för hållbart företagande och mänskliga rättigheter för att förbättra regionens konkurrenskraftiga position för att locka investeringar och öka handelsflöden.

description.narrative: 2019 was the first year of full implementation of the Business and Human Rights Asia programme following the first 5 months of the set-up phase in 2018. Key achievements were delivered within the first year including; -The adoption of Thailand National Action Plan (NAP) on B+HR by the government which is the first NAP in Asia -Zero draft of India NAP -The first South Asia Forum on BHR in New Delhi, India in March 2019 -In collaboration with OECD, the Responsible Business and Human Rights Forum took place in Bangkok, Thailand in June 2019 which was the first OECD RBF which hosted outside Paris. -The development and lanuch of Gender guidance toolkit complementary to UNGP BHR at the global forum on BHR in Geneva in November 2019. -Grants provided to regional CSOs namely Asia NGO Coaltion (ANGOC) and Centre for Environmental Concerns (CEC) for support to HRDs related. ANGOC is focused at advocacy for land rights and CEC aims to convene and strengthen monitoring and documentation of environmental and human rights violations, and capacity building of grassroots environmental HRDs. It is anticipated that the support to regional CSOs would increase the attention and accountability of the duty bearer and the business to the environmental human rights defenders. -Programme outreach in a year: B+HR Asia worked directly with 14 Asian States and 10 NHRIs and 8 UN actors in addition to the OECD. The project supported awareness-capacity building sessions for over 1500 civil society representatives and 200+ business representatives. B+HR Asia reached out to 1100+ and created over 505K impressions through its social media platforms. -New partnerships with donors and other actors including the EU, the Switzerland government, one private company in India and private foundation. These new partnerships support the implementation of the programme or activities at specific country level. The support from the EU covers 5 countries out of 7 countries of B+HR Asia programme. Funding from Switzerland, company and foundation are targeted at specific country in accordance with the scope of each initiativew which are Pakistan, India and Bangladesh respectively. -Enhanced peer to peer learning (south-South exchange) - Thailand as the first country in Asia adopting the NAP BHR shared its knowledge and experiences with other Asian countries that have an interest in developing the NAP. Pakistan officials visited Thailand for their learning. At the global BHR Forum, Indonesia confirmed its commitment in learning from Thailand about the NAP development. -B+HR Asia programme was selected by the Development Cooperation section at the Embassy as one of the contributions to be evaluated on the integration of environmental perspective in the programme. The programme staff also participated in the environmental workshop organized by the Embassy. By the end of 2019 at the submission of the 2020 annual workplan, the programme intened to implement 'Greening the B+HR Asia' at operational level such as selecting the meeting premises that adopt environmental policy, encourage paperless programme materials and communication, etc. This demonstrated the effort and commitment of the programme in integrating the environmental aspect in the implementation. It is also worth to highlight the unexpected results achieved by the programme which are; -Through the regional awareness raising activities, advocacy missions and positive communications by the programme, the momentum and interest on BHR agenda has reached out beyond the programme geographical coverage of 7 countries. The programme was contacted for follow-up discussions and activities regarding the possibility of initial steps towards the implementation of UNGP BHR in Pakistan, Nepal and Maldives. -Collaboration with new stakeholders and complementary initiative at the country-level that has already engaged in the area of governance and business sustainability. At the BHR Lab in 2019, the event was also observed by the representatives from Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) of Thailand - the regulating body for the listed companies and stock exchange of Thailand. SEC has started encouraging Thai listed companies to undertake Hmuan Rights Due Diligence in accordance with one of the measures identified in the NAP. In addition to the results at regional level, the status at the country-level is also of importance. When it comes to the NAP process update - Thailand and India are the leading countries (the former launched the NAP in December 2019 and the zero draft of the NAP was formulated for the latter). The level of progress is followed by Indonesia and Malaysia. It was expected Indonesia to adopt a policy document related to Business and Human Rights in 2020. Malaysia confirmed the NAP drafting process in 2019 which was a good signal for the next step. The Country Offices in Bangladesh and Viet Nam continues to increase its effort to secure the sufficient level of political buy-in to advocate for a NAP. Sri Lanka is probably the one most lagging behind. Below are the summary of the progress in each country; India - First South Asia Forum on B+HR and the launch of zero draft NAP in parallel with multi-stakeholders consultation. B+HR Asia has invested hugely in developing and strengthening the relationship with the Ministry of Corporate Affairs (MCA), the leading Ministry responsible for developing and implementing the NAP in India. Upon request from the MCA, UNDP embedded a consultant within the Ministry to provide support on research and organising consultations with the relevant stakeholders. The strategy proved successful in ensuring up-to-date information on the progress made within the MCA in relation to NAP development and ensuring the voices of right-holders are included in the development process. The programme witnessed a growing interest of private sector actors in the BHR agenda. B+HR Asia connected with several key players, for example, Aditya Birla Group (ABG) to advise on and to develop tools that would measure the impact of business operations on human rights and the environment. ABG’s Head of Sustainability gave a license to UNDP to share its toolkit, now under development, with other companies. Vietnam - priliminary assessment of the regulatory framework on B+HR. Viet Nam’s progress was stalled by political challenges, and reiterated by an engaged and empowered, yet overstretched capacity in the CO. However, currently, the UNDP Viet Nam CO is supporting the development of a baseline study on the BHR and the environment, through an ‘inclusive business’ lens. The CO has worked within a responsible business discourse, as compared to the regional BHR discourse, to better accommodate stakeholders’ expectations, including the preferred discourse of the government Indonesia - creation of the steering committee on B+HR, the establishment of national task force on BHR. the Roadmap on BHR 2020-2024 The Government of Indonesia is finalizing the draft National Action Plan on Human Rights as they have received the list of priority actions related to the rights of children, women, indigenous people and people with disabilities. The action plan is expected to be launched in Q1 of 2020, and a chapter specifically on BHR is highly anticipated. Malaysia - renewed commitment to drafting the NAP. Malaysia is moving forward to improve its human rights record. The Strategic Framework for the NAP was drafted by the Malaysian National Human Rights Commission, (SUHAKAM). In 2019, the change of the government in Malaysia required advocacy for a renewed commitment. Despite various challenges, UNDP has successfully advocated with the new government to re-confirm the policy commitment on BHR that was formalized in June, during the National High-level Dialogue organized by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and UNDP. Sri Lanka - inaugural responsible business and human rights national dialogue in October 2019. Series of coordinated bombings conducted by religious extremists created an unfavourable situation in the country. The society was shaken and CSOs were focusing on ensuring peace and harmony, while the government put restrictions in place to discourage the spread of hatred and violence in the country. This unfortunate environment impacted the UNDP CO’s capacity to prioritize business and human rights project. Despite the challenges in the country and its post-conflict status, a growing cross-sectoral enthusiasm to advance the BHR agenda can be observed Bangladesh - national and provincial dialogues on B+HR private sector engagement. Through missions and technical support provided to UNDP Bangladesh, it has been assessed that there is an interest in developing a NAP by multiple government actors. However, it doesn’t yet appear to be a priority. Various events and meetings were organised with the government representatives to build their capacity and promote uptake of the BHR agenda. UNDP Bangladesh will continue to engage with government representatives and provide opportunities for peer-learning. On the other hand, B+HR Asia has been successful in advocating for the Human Rights Commission of Bangladesh (NHRCB) to play a convening role, and indeed the NHRC is championing the BHR agenda. The NHRCB has also been actively engaged in pushing the BHR agenda in the country. The work of B+HR Asia in Bangladesh is aligned with an existing initiative named Human Rights Programme (HRP). Regional Consultations were held in Chattogram and Sylhet. The consultations were attended by 100+ participants from the private sector, CSOs and local administration including the Deputy Commissioner, Chattogram. These consultations helped decentralise the efforts to promote BHR in the country and helped bringing attention to two key business sectors (shipbreaking in Chattogram and tea production in Sylhet) affecting human rights in the country. In summary, country-level interventions have been fundamental in driving the BHR progress by building capacity, raising awareness and providing platforms to strengthen collaboration. The in-country work strengthened BHR policies and legal frameworks, led to higher interest and enthusiasm among stakeholders, created awareness, and enhanced South-South cooperation. Despite these developments, the year included various unforeseen challenges. The capacity of COs was often overstretched, which resulted in lower than expected delivery rates. These reflections have led to UNDP allocating resources in 2020 for two full-time National B+HR Officer, based in Viet Nam and Bangladesh. While all 7 countries originally in focus will still be receiving support, the regional BHR Asia has decided that the EU-supported project leads in countries of geographical overlap and shift more resources from Sweden to Vietnam and Bangladesh - the countries that are not in focus in the EU programme.
